column1: The COVID-19 pandemic in Brunei is part of the worldwide pandemic of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2). The virus spread to Brunei on 9 March 2020
column2: when its first case was confirmed in Tutong. Many early cases were linked to Jamek Mosque Sri Petaling in Kuala Lumpur
column3: which held a large Tablighi Jamaat ijtema event at the end of February 2020. Of Brunei's first 50 cases
column4: 45 were related to Jamek Mosque.  The pandemic had spread to all districts of Brunei
column5: except in the exclave of Temburong.

column2: the World Health Organization (WHO) confirmed that a novel coronavirus was the cause of a respiratory illness in a cluster of people in Wuhan City
column5: which was reported to the WHO on 31 December 2019. The case fatality ratio for COVID-19 has been much lower than SARS of 2003
column6: but the transmission has been significantly greater
column7: with a significant total death toll.

column2: the Ministry of Health confirmed that preliminary coronavirus tests had returned positive for a 53-year-old male who had returned from a tabligh (Muslim religious gathering) in Kuala Lumpur
column3: Malaysia on 3 March. The patient began to experience symptoms on 7 March
column4: and was eventually moved to the National Isolation Centre in Tutong for treatment. The ministry is following up with the three friends he had travelled with
column5: and with the patient's family members.On 10 March
column6: the Health Ministry reported five more cases of the coronavirus
column7: bringing the total to six. These five individuals were close contacts of the first case and were isolated for treatment at the National Isolation Centre in Tutong.On 11 March
column8: the Health Ministry reported five new cases
column9: bringing the total number to 11. Three of these individuals had attended the tabligh in Kuala Lumpur on 3 March.On 12 March
column10: the Health Ministry confirmed 14 new cases
column11: bringing the total number to 25. Ten of these cases were linked to the same Islamic missionary gathering in Kuala Lumpur that the first confirmed patient had attended. Three of the cases were close contacts of the confirmed patients while the last case was a 64-year-old man who had been to Kuala Lumpur and Cambodia.On 14 March
column12: the Health Ministry reported that Brunei had a total of 40 cases of the coronavirus.On 15 March
column14: bringing the total number to 50.On 22 March
column17: bringing the total number to 91.On 24 March
column18: the Health Ministry confirmed 13 new cases
column19: the highest since the first case on 9 March
column20: bringing the total number to 104.On 25 March
column25: with 11 recoveries to-date. In the evening
column26: the first case of death occurs.On 5 May
column27: one new COVID-19 case has been confirmed
column28: bringing the total active case to 139. On the next day
column29: 2 related cases were detected involving the case detected on the previous day.On 2 June
column30: most schools partially reopened and the majority of classes resumed as normal.On 7 August
column31: Brunei reported one imported case after 91 days of zero positive cases. The carrier was a local man travelling from Yemen.

column2: Brunei announced entry restrictions for people coming from China. Starting February 1
column3: temperature screening was implemented on entry to the country. Royal Brunei Airlines reduced flights to China. In response to the coronavirus pandemic
column4: the Ministry of Education announced that the first school term break scheduled for 16 March 2020 would be moved forward to 11 March.On 14 March
column5: the Brunei Ministry of Health ordered 638 people to go into quarantine. The Ministry has also stepped up efforts to track more close contacts of positive cases.On 15 March
column6: the Bruneian Government barred all citizens and foreign residents from leaving as a result of the coronavirus pandemic. The Ministry of Health has also banned mass gatherings including weddings and sporting events. In addition the National Football Association of Brunei Darussalam
column7: the  Tutong District Amateur Football Association League
column8: and the Brunei Basketball Association suspended all matches and games.On 16 March
column9: the Ministry of Religious Affairs announced a one-week closure for all mosques in the country
column11: and the Friday prayers which coincided with this time were suspended. However
column12: the adhan or Islamic prayer calls would still be conducted. The Bruneian Government also announced that the Temburong Bridge would be opened on the following day
column14: to ease travelling to the Temburong District exclave after the government announced outbound travel ban. Previously
column15: commuters have to drive through the Malaysian Limbang District or take passenger ferry services. At initial opening
column16: the bridge was opened from 6 am to 10 pm and traffic is only allowed for Brunei-registered vehicles.

column2: on the first day of opening
column3: citizens were seen flocking to Temburong
column4: taking advantage of the bridge for pleasure purposes. The government then changed the opening time of the bridge to 6 am to 6 pm as a precautionary measure to reduce the spread of COVID. On 23 May 2020 the opening hours of the bridge were extended back to their original times.
